The following novella is Ms. Eberhardt’s final work. A bold experiment in what she called “alternative biography," Ms. Eberhardt conducts a destructuralist exploration of an imagined life in which she died at the age of 27 in Algeria. Although the life of the fictional Isabelle Eberhardt bears little resemblance to her eponymous creator, Ms. Eberhardt had commented that “it is the ideas that connect our experiences more than any earnest autobiographer could perform.”

IE: And rightfully so. Perhaps as a creator I am prone to surreptitious imagery and kaleidoscopic speculations, but I have images and visions so vivid that they could only be memories. As you may also remember, my natural ability and almost uncanny affinity to French literature, especially of Francophone accounts of North Africa, also troubled me with its emotionality. I think the fictional Isabelle should be born in Switzerland in the late 1870s, but I chose to kept the details of my Manchester upbringing in my manuscript.

IE: I firmly believe that she is real, as I firmly believe in the fictitiousness of my own existence. I think of myself as a part of a soul she forgot to claim when she threw herself into the flood, and I long to unite with her.

As Isabelle’s childhood friend, I include within firsthand commentary on her early years, inclusive of a discussion on her education, gender identity and the nature of the female intimacy we experienced as children.

Note: After discussions with Mr. Lyautey, we have agreed that perhaps inserting footnotes in these chapters is the best way to enlighten the reader on the correlations between the fictional Isabelle and Ms. Eberhardt’s own life. Isabelle Magnolia Eberhardt was born in Manchester, England on the fifteenth of June, 1956. She had two sisters, Juliette Rose Eberhardt and Anna Lavender Eberhardt. Their mother, Maria Theresa Eberhardt (nee Smith) was from a rich but unimportant family. Her father, Jonathan William Woods was from the exact opposite. He came from a northern mining family with roots just south of Carlisle. The unlikely couple met outside, not inside, of a local pub in Lancaster that his father often visited. In the 1930s, Lancaster Castle was not yet the notorious prison that it was known until the early 2010s, but was a police training school. Far more open to the public than a gaol, Maria would often walk the area outside, marveling at the Norman architecture. This would lead her up and down Castle Hill almost daily, as she would go most mornings, and down to the corner of Market Street where she would have a cup of tea.
